title: Boot on USB on old PC

forumNotes.author: jibux
forumNotes.content:
Hello,  

I've a bootable USB, and I want to boot on it on an old PC.  
I've a freedos bootable diskette with a right driver to see my USB disk on D:  

I wanted to use grub4dos to chain to the syslinux present on my USB disk.  

Unfortunately it can't access on hd1,0 because it uses bios.  

Is there any solution for my issue ?  

Thanks.

forumNotes.author: megaborg
forumNotes.content:
Probably **Plop boot manager** could be useful to you: infact it is a small program to boot different operating systems from harddisk, floppy, CD/DVD or from USB  
[http://blog.brothers...ted-using-plop/](http://blog.brothersoft.com/2008/12/09/boot-computer-from-usb-or-cdrom-even-if-bios-not-supported-using-plop/ "External link")

forumNotes.author: jibux
forumNotes.content:
Thank you very much for this information. That's exactly that I need. And it's really simpler than FreeDos+driverUSB+grub4dos+boot on syslinux.  

Unfortunately, plop recognizes my USB key, but it freezes on LOADING BOOT SECTOR...

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> Thank you very much for this information. That's exactly that I need. And it's really simpler than FreeDos+driverUSB+grub4dos+boot on syslinux.  
>
> Unfortunately, plop recognizes my USB key, but it freezes on LOADING BOOT SECTOR...

That could also be related to the actual way the stick was partitioned/formatted and which MBR code (and bootsector code) is used on it.  

In other words it is possible that the incompatibility is not between PloP and your motherboard, but between your motherboard and the way the stick is partitioned/formatted or between PloP ant the way your stick is partitioned formatted.  

Please post some details on the stick, the tools you used, which filesystem(s) are on it, etc.  

jaclaz

forumNotes.content:

This is the content of main directory ``` -rwx------ 1 jeb root 144 2009-05-06 20:44 autorun.inf drwx------ 2 jeb root 4096 2009-05-06 20:47 casper -rwx------ 1 jeb root 134217728 2009-05-06 20:48 casper-rw -rwx------ 1 jeb root 1020 2009-04-20 00:35 cdromupgrade drwx------ 2 jeb root 4096 2009-05-06 20:47 .disk drwx------ 3 jeb root 4096 2009-05-06 20:47 dists drwx------ 3 jeb root 4096 2009-05-06 09:05 doc drwx------ 2 jeb root 4096 2009-04-25 20:36 Documents drwx------ 2 jeb root 4096 2009-05-06 20:47 install -r-x------ 1 jeb root 14607 2009-05-06 20:44 ldlinux.sys -rwx------ 1 jeb root 4987 2009-05-06 20:44 md5sum.txt drwx------ 2 jeb root 4096 2009-05-06 20:47 pics drwx------ 5 jeb root 4096 2009-05-06 20:47 pool drwx------ 2 jeb root 4096 2009-05-06 20:47 preseed -rwx------ 1 jeb root 227 2009-05-06 20:44 README.diskdefines drwx------ 2 jeb root 8192 2009-05-06 20:47 syslinux -rwx------ 1 jeb root 76 2009-05-06 20:47 syslinux.cfg -rwx------ 1 jeb root 93729 2009-05-06 09:11 ubnfilel.txt -rwx------ 1 jeb root 5042038 2009-04-21 16:22 ubninit -rwx------ 1 jeb root 3501776 2009-04-21 16:22 ubnkern -rwx------ 1 jeb root 25607 2009-05-06 09:05 ubnpathl.txt -rwx------ 1 jeb root 199517 2008-09-17 15:14 umenu.exe -rwx------ 1 jeb root 144392 2009-05-06 09:11 vesamenu.c32 -rwx------ 1 jeb root 1533687 2009-05-06 20:44 wubi.exe ```
It's a vfat type file system /media/XUBUNTU type vfat (rw,nosuid,nodev,uhelper=hal,shortname=mixed,uid=1000,utf8,umask=077,flush)

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
Basically it should be a wrap-around based on PartED (and syslinux):  
[http://packages.ubun...pid/usb-creator](http://packages.ubuntu.com/intrepid/usb-creator "External link")  

vfat translated to us DOS users should mean FAT16 LBA addressed ![:D](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/biggrin.png)  

Can you check with beeblebrox:  
[http://students.cs.byu.edu/\~codyb/](http://students.cs.byu.edu/~codyb/ "External link")  
or with an equivalent Linux utility the DATA in the MBR and post them?  

How big is the key?  

Can you try installing the grub4dos grldr.mbr and see if you get the same error?  

jaclaz

forumNotes.author: jibux
forumNotes.content:
> Can you check the DATA in the MBR and post them?  
>
> jaclaz

```
sudo dd if=/dev/sdf of=mbr.bin bs=512 count=1
```

![Posted Image](http://jebissey.free.fr/pictures/mbr-keypenUbuntu.png)  

It is a 4GB key  

I will try to install the grub4dos grldr.mbr and let you know the result this week end (I have to hit the book a little before, because I just discover it yesterday.  

Thanks again for your help.

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
Cannot say why and how, but the partition data is wrong. The Vfat is a 0B kind of partition i.e. FAT32 CHS.
The part that now reads: ``` 80 01 01 00 0B 7E FE FE 3E 00 00 00 00 E9 7A 00 00 00 ``` should read: ``` 80 01 01 00 0B FE 7F F4 3F 00 00 00 76 CF 7A 00 00 00 ```
In "human readable" format, your current partition appears like: 0B/80/0/1/1/1.022/126/62/62/8.055.040 while it should be: 0B/80/0 /1/1/500/254/63 /63/8.048.502 It seems like the device, instead of the "right" ***n*** x255x**63** geometry has been detected with a 62 sectors geometry, than the 1022 is simply wrong as it nears the 8Gb boundary. Finally CHS and LBA are definitely unbablanced. What I would do: * save/backup the contents of the partition * correct the data in the MBR as above * re-format the partition and restore the saved files and run syslinux to recreate the bootsector (or try re-running the utility you used but skipping the partitioning step - if possible)
jaclaz

forumNotes.author: jibux
forumNotes.content:
I reformat my USB key, and now I noticed it's a Fat32/LBA type (0x0C).  
When I boot on computer able to boot on USB key it's OK.  
But when I boot with plop with the old PC, it freezes  

This is my new mbr.  
![Posted Image](http://jebissey.free.fr/pictures/mbr-Xubuntu(2).png)  

I wonder if this one is not correct too, how actual bios are able to boot with.  

Thanks again for your help

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> I wonder if this one is not correct too, how actual bios are able to boot with. Rest assured, it is not correct as well. ![:D](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/biggrin.png)
BIOS may use one of two "conventions" for addressing a sector. CHS or LBA. Theoretically, a BIOS that "sees" a LBA id for the partition, like the 0C you now have, should ignore the CHS data. On the other hand, if a partition has a CHS id, like the 0B you had before, it should ignore the LBA data and use CHS. Then, the particular booting OS may use one or the other convention. Theory and reality are as often happens completely different. There are reports of the strangest things happening with USB devices, mainly due to the queer or non-standard way the BIOS detects the device. A short list is in FAQ#10: [http://home.graffiti...SB/USBfaqs.html](http://home.graffiti.net/jaclaz:graffiti.net/Projects/USB/USBfaqs.html "External link") I am not familiar with the tool you are using or more generally with Linux tools, thus there may be some misunderstandings in the procedure. Both your "old" DATA and the "new" ones don't make any sense, it seems like there is a detection problem of some kind or however a misfunctioning of the tools you are using. The "new" data corresponds to: 0C/80/0/0/2/501/196/15/1/8.060.927 Which has a lot of problems (but that could be ininfluent on a motherboard and OS that uses ONLY LBA addresses) Additionally, at least for the FAT32 bootsector CODE that is used in Windows NT/2K/XP/2003 - but the same may be possible on the one used under Linux ![:D](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/biggrin.png), there are more problems. Don't you have a machine running Windows? Or DOS? Or any way under Linux to simply use an hex-editor or a partition editor to write the "right" data I suggested you before, then re-format the device? Additionally it might be a good idea to start from scratch, by deleting (wiping) the first say 100 sectors with dd or a similar utility. I can point you to several threads here on the board where the matter is discussed, but they all use DOS/Windows tools, so there might be a problem to find the corresponding Linux utility. Ideally, after wiping the first sectors of that stick, you should try using RMPREPUSB.EXE, the new kid on the block that comes with a number of small but useful improvements for increasing the bootability of a stick: [http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=7739](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=7739 "External link") jaclaz

forumNotes.author: jibux
forumNotes.content:
Thanks again for all your explanations. Boot on USB stick is definitively a long way. Because my windows system is realy strange, and also because I've been using linux for 9 years, I would try to fix this problem with Linux tools. So I created a new dos partition table with ***gparted*** (a free graphical tools like partition magic). And ***fdisk*** command line tools reports : ``` Disque /dev/sdg: 4127 Mo, 4127195136 octets 127 têtes, 62 secteurs/piste, 1023 cylindres Unités = cylindres de 7874 * 512 = 4031488 octets Identifiant de disque : 0x0000675b ```
It is sound good isn't it ? And this is the MBR ![Posted Image](http://jebissey.free.fr/pictures/mbr_after_gparted.png) After, I formated all USB disk in FAT32 format with ***gparted*** . And ***fdisk*** reports : ``` sudo fdisk -l /dev/sdg Disque /dev/sdg: 4127 Mo, 4127195136 octets 127 têtes, 62 secteurs/piste, 1023 cylindres Unités = cylindres de 7874 * 512 = 4031488 octets Identifiant de disque : 0x0000675b Périphérique Amorce Début Fin Blocs Id Système /dev/sdg1 1 1023 4027520 b W95 FAT32 ```

And this is the MBR ![Posted Image](http://jebissey.free.fr/pictures/mbr_after_FAT32.png) Let me know if all is good until now.

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> So I created a new dos partition table with ***gparted*** (a free graphical tools like partition magic). ![:D](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/biggrin.png) a "linux guy" actually trusting a graphical tool! :wink: DO NOT trust ANY graphical tool, EVER, if not EXPLICITLY told so! :smile:

> And ***fdisk*** command line tools reports : > > ``` > Disque /dev/sdg: 4127 Mo, 4127195136 octets > > 127 têtes, 62 secteurs/piste, 1023 cylindres > > Unités = cylindres de 7874 * 512 = 4031488 octets > > Identifiant de disque : 0x0000675b > ``` > >
> > It is sound good isn't it ? > >
> **NO** , it does ***NOT*** . ![:D](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/biggrin.png) A hard disk (read USB stick) should be seen as having 6**3** "secteurs/piste" (and 255 "têtes"). I don't want to seem unhelpful, mind you :wink:, but I already told what you should try to do. You cannot "skip" my questions and insist using the tools you "like" (since they are NOT working). Get a @ç#ing hex/disk editor and write the values I gave you before. (post #8). Then disconnect and reconnect the stick and run fdisk on it, and post the result. Before that, you may want to read the "common sense advice" attached to Rules: [http://www.boot-land...?act=boardrules](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?act=boardrules "External link") with particular regards to points #f., #f.3, #f.4 :wink: You can try to see if the java linux version of beeblebrox works on your machine: [http://beeblebrox.org/software.php](http://beeblebrox.org/software.php "External link") [http://sf.net/projects/beeblebrox](http://sf.net/projects/beeblebrox "External link") [http://sourceforge.n...use_mirror=garr](http://sourceforge.net/project/downloading.php?groupname=beeblebrox&filename=beeblebrox-linux-0.0.3.tar.gz&use_mirror=garr "External link") Do you have Open Office or any program capable to access an Excel Spreadsheet? I could give you a preview of my CHS_LBA_V2.xls, that adds to the functionalities of the old CHS-LBA.xls: [http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=2959](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/?showtopic=2959 "External link") the translation from DATA to HEX Partition Table and viceversa, so that you can play with the values. :wink: jaclaz

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> ..image of hex-editor... I do trust your being able to copy a few bytes. :wink: I meant the result of > Then disconnect and reconnect the stick and run fdisk on it, and post the result. I would have loved to see something like this: \[WARNING PSEUDO-CODE\] > Disque /dev/sdg: 4127 Mo, 4127195136 octets > **255** têtes, 6**3** secteurs/piste, **501** cylindres > Unités = cylindres de 7874 \* 512 = 4031488 octets > Identifiant de disque : 0x0000675b \[/WARNING PSEUDO-CODE\] > I admit it's not very polite for the time you spent to answer and I apologize for that. No problem ![:D](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/biggrin.png), but you see, we have a "double language barrier" (Italian\<-\>English\<-\>French) and a OS barrier (DOS/Windows\<-\>Linux) to which you add that it is one of your first posts, so I cannot "imagine" how deep is your knowledge and familiarity with the matter and tools and how much my English is understandable, while you don't know how much I am familiar with the Linux tools you are using (and more generally with Linux thingies). So we need to be very "exact" in the exchange of informations, the Tower of Babel got never finished for similar reasons. ![:D](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/biggrin.png) Another example: > Thanks for all links for tools and information. You're right on linux system it's possible to run java programs and work with Excel document thanks to OpenOffice. I do know that java works on Linux and that OpenOffice.org can open Excel files, thank you. :smile: What I asked was different: > You can try to see if the java linux version of beeblebrox works on your machine: > [http://beeblebrox.org/software.php](http://beeblebrox.org/software.php "External link") > [http://sf.net/projects/beeblebrox](http://sf.net/projects/beeblebrox "External link") > [http://sourceforge.n...use_mirror=garr](http://sourceforge.net/project/downloading.php?groupname=beeblebrox&filename=beeblebrox-linux-0.0.3.tar.gz&use_mirror=garr "External link") Means: I know perfectly well that java runs under Linux but I don't know if this specific java based app runs on your specific Linux machine/distro, TRY AND SEE IF IT WORKS in your environment. The old Windows version runs under Windows, while the new Windows java version does not (at least on my machine). A partition table editor is an easier way to exchange info in "human readable" form (as opposed to hex bytes or hex-editor screenshots). As well this: > Do you have Open Office or any program capable to access an Excel Spreadsheet? It's a plain and simple question that only accepts a YES or a NO answer :wink:: I know perfectly well that Open Office can open Excel spreadsheet, but DO YOU HAVE IT (or any other program capable of doing so)?
> If it's possible I prefer to use very basic tools, so with ***dd*** and ***hexedit*** and ***fdisk***, I think I'm able to follow your instructions. OK, let's see how it goes on. What happens when you run fdisk on the stick with the modified "modified" MBR data? Does it detect the new data or it still thinks that the device is 1023/127/62? I seem to remember that it is fdisk **-p** :wink: to show current Partition table data.
:wink: jaclaz

forumNotes.author: jibux
forumNotes.content:
> What happens when you run fdisk on the stick with the modified "modified" MBR data? ``` sudo fdisk -l /dev/sdg Disque /dev/sdg: 4127 Mo, 4127195136 octets 255 têtes, 63 secteurs/piste, 501 cylindres Unités = cylindres de 16065 * 512 = 8225280 octets Identifiant de disque : 0x0000675b Périphérique Amorce Début Fin Blocs Id Système /dev/sdg1 * 1 501 4024251 b W95 FAT32 ```
> Does it detect the new data or it still thinks that the device is 1023/127/62? I seem to remember that it is fdisk **-p** ![:D](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/biggrin.png) to show current Partition table data. Actually if you only want to list partition you can use -l, but this is the full method ``` sudo fdisk /dev/sdg Commande (m pour l'aide): p Disque /dev/sdg: 4127 Mo, 4127195136 octets 255 têtes, 63 secteurs/piste, 501 cylindres Unités = cylindres de 16065 * 512 = 8225280 octets Identifiant de disque : 0x0000675b Périphérique Amorce Début Fin Blocs Id Système /dev/sdg1 * 1 501 4024251 b W95 FAT32 Commande (m pour l'aide): q ```

I think it's the good way to work together. Because my english is quite limited, only few questions / explanations with brief comments it's good for me. But probably it's difficult to ask to an Italian brief comments ! ![:D](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/biggrin.png) :wink:

> Identifiant de disque : 0x0000675b

:wink:  

jaclaz
